ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a much more extensive knowledge of American Sign Language as well as Deaf culture.
ASL Grammar, Vocab, other basic skills

- increased signing vocabulary
- better understanding of ASL grammar and storytelling
- better understanding of Deaf culture

I learned more vocabulary to make my vocabulary more extensive to enhance my conversational and storytelling skills. My service project this semester also allowed me to gain insights into my chosen topic from Deaf perspective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strengths are definitely the low-stress mode of instruction. I never felt stressed about the class but I still feel like I learned a lot throughout the course of it which made it a really enjoyable experience. The professors are great and all of the assessments, projects, and homework assignments are very low stress but also very informative. I don't think there are really any weaknesses, the course was really great!
Could use a more specified format. Often assignments were given with no notice in advance

A strength of course was it relying on conversations, stories, projects, and vocabulary review rather than just homework and tests. A weakness was sometimes miscommunication on important things such as exams.
I believe that ASL is one of the best structured languages at Yale. Im not sure I have any critiques for the course.

Wonderful course!
Strengths: 
- Service learning aspect is great. 
- Incremental introduction and review of vocabulary is nice (when it happens this way)
- Frances Conlin is wonderful. Generous, compassionate, dedicated teacher. Should receive a more substantive position at the University.

Weaknesses: (maybe the class, but I suspect the program which includes multiple classes all kept on the same syllabus)
- Emphasis on memorization of obscure semantic and grammatical terms / postulates. Memorizing the names of the different categories of classifiers isn't nearly as important as being able to understand and use the different classifiers. Why would identifying them by obscure names be a fifth of the final? 
- Poor organization with respect to receiving work back. Had no idea where 2/3 of my homework was, then received it back and learned it was being graded on correctness.  
- The fixed syllabus also makes it very difficult for us to work on the things our class is struggling with particularly (even when Prof C says "we'll work on that"). That's a real shame...

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. ASL is a really useful language and the professors are really great about teaching it in a low-stress yet very effective way. I think if you're looking to start a new language at Yale this is definitely a really great option.
Definitely! ASL is a language that anyone can learn, and it can be learned here at Yale well. The instructors are all amazing and super sweet.
Yes, it teaches ASL very effectively and showcases Deaf culture very well. It teaches you to look at the world and its issues through a different perspective.
I would definitely recommend ASL to all students, I think that the course is amazing and that learning ASL really helps the greater community and helps with inclusivity.
Yes. Wonderful professor, beautiful language, really nice students.
